comments.commentBody:
Pie in the sky ideas. Building pipelines for a few million gallons of oil are one thing, building them to supply water to a whole city is another. The Columbia River has a good supply, but to get any of it to California would require massive amounts of energy, and massive pipelines across private and public lands, then over the hills if it could be done.

California's farmers are going to have to change the kids of crops they grow. They will have to grow more seasonal ones, and stop planting almonds. The country's biggest cotton grower the Boswell Corp. will have to plant some other crop.

We get the majority of our water in the central valley from the Sierra Nevada, and in the north from the Siskiyous, with some from the Klamath that arises in Oregon.

The farmers in the San Joaquin Valley dried up Tulare Lake with the building of Friant Dam on the Kings river; Now they are paying for it as the ground water is not being replenished.

Henry Miller of Miller Lux was the owner of more California land than any other person, but he did not farm it, he used it for grazing lands.

The Colorado River has far less water flowing than when the previous allotments among the states were made. The MWD has had to give up 500 million Cu ft, from it.

Even where I live, we have had to cut back. The Sacramento River is just 5 miles west of me, and the American 5 miles east, and they look like they have a good supply, but they do not, as the reservoirs are getting low.

Reply to JMF: guidelines say to offer what one can safely do, from TOLAC for everyone to no TOLACs. Rural hospitals especially are affected, as documented in recent NYT article, where expectant mother was SHOCKED, SHOCKED that the little rural Idaho hospital in her little town would not agree to TOLAC. A little patient reality therapy is needed, as well as more in-depth reporting by NYT. This little rural hospital doesn't have a PET scanner either!

You didn't read the article very well. It makes it clear that she did not "lay quietly on the operating table," as you claim. It says: "The hospital record leaves little question that the operation was conducted against her will: “I have decided to override her refusal to have a C-section,” a handwritten note signed by Dr. James J. Ducey, the director of maternal and fetal medicine, says, adding that her doctor and the hospital’s lawyer had agreed.

“I was begging, give me another hour, give me another two hours,” Mrs. Dray said. Her mother, who was there, supported her, and the doctor said, “I’m not bargaining here,” Mrs. Dray said.

Mrs. Dray said she kept begging on the operating table. His answer, she recalled, was, “Don’t speak.”

I don't know if you have ever experienced labor, but you're not physically in a position to wrestle with anyone at that point. And if you've ever found yourself in a hospital, you would know that the people with the knives and needles have all the power.

Detroit is being run by its public employees. The emergency manager is busy executing the contrived and unnecessary bankruptcy instigated by the Republican governor and the Republican legislature..

Oh, we absolutely have to go into bankruptcy because of public employee pensions. Oh, we can fix 90% of the problem with a $198B allocation from the legislature. Oh, we legislators won't go along with the deal unless we can deny Detroit residents the vote for the next 20 years.

If real people we're being hurt by this charade, you could produce it as a farce on Broadway.

We could easily add a meaningful disincentive to excess influence of a few big donors.

We ought to do intensive criminal investigations of what they get for their money. It ought to be just like what the IRS does each tax season -- make a few examples of the worst offenders every election. It must have a punishment that counts, not a slap on the wrist, it must lead to jail for both donor and politician.

A few of those every two years would clean things up too. It is already illegal, just do it.

I know that this article is about Vanessa but it is just as important to assure that her Mom still has an opportunity to go to college. Why not? There are scores if not hundreds of very good college programs that work with older students than she. She too is still as competent a learner as she needs to be to increase her knowledge and intellectual skills until she has proven to herself and her college that she deserves a bachelor's degree in a subject of her choice.
I applaud Dr. Laude for all he has done already and Dr. Yeager and his colleagues for continuing their highly successful work. If we could all work just as hard and effectively to assure better income distribution in our nation, we would then assure that students like Vanessa would succeed in college at significantly higher rates and fewer of them would need TIP programs.
Frankly, the best thing that could happen would be for childbirth to be de-medicalized.

The truth, I'm sure, lies somewhere between the lines on this one.

Having had a successful VBAC, I know I had to push for every non-intervention I received with my 2nd (no pitocin, no AFI, no IUPC, etc). I am a doc so I was able to get more of what I wanted without being labeled a loon. As another poster stated, the difference between a vaginal delivery and a surgical one are night and day. I'd have 10 more kids vaginally before I'd have a single one surgically again.

As a doc, however, I recognize a doc's need to practice defensively. For OBs malpractice is sky high and, given the awful work hours, the numbers of trainees entering OB are decreasing. Becoming more and more common as well are the OB hospitalists who cover deliveries for a 12-24 hour shift. They don't know the patients; they don't care about the patients; they do what is needed to avoid being sued or losing their job. Cases like these are pushing labor and delivery into a system no one wants to be in as a patient. I'm glad my childbearing years are behind me.

You don't think there are female OB-GYNS who would have made the decision to section her? First of all, we don't know any of the details behind the doctor's decision. Was the mother or child in danger, or did he need to get to an important dinner and wanted to hasten the birth. (I don't believe the later is common). Why did she waste her money on a doctor who has studied his/her craft for at least eight years when she, the patient, knows more?  At the very least, if Mrs. Dray decides to have a 4th child, she should find a doctor who would absolutely agree to follow her directives and ignore what makes medical sense.
Is that legal precedent controlling in NY?  Even if not, the specter of a similar suit would likely incentivize performing c-sections.
The "right to refuse treatment, even if it results in your death." Fine. But if it results in the death or neurological or physical damage to her child?

This mother will sue if something happens to her fetus as the result of a vaginal delivery and that will cost the doctor and the hospital much more not to mention that her fetus has been harmed (even though it was her call/fault.)  Better to confront a lawsuit by a disgruntled mother -- it is much more likely to be winnable plus no one was irreparably harmed.  Good luck Ms. Dray if you ever need another doctor to deliver another baby for you.

Doctors who cannot accept the typical ups and downs of practice should not be doctors.  Any doctor who would make such a call within ear shot of her patient and makes it clear she's furious needs to lose her license.  It would appear that patient care is the last thing on her mind.

This is what I would do to help in the recovery of your PTSD. Firstly, write a letter to this fateful physician, telling her what you have said her. Send a copy to yourself through the U.S. mail, but do not ope the letter. Then, unannounced, appear at the physicians office on a day that you know she will be seeing patients. Ask to speak with the the physician, always maintaining control, but be firm, and if she refuses to see you, let it be known your dissatisfaction, do this by making sure your voice is clear and respectful. Go home, write another letter, send a copy again to yourself, do not open. Send a copy to the state oversight agency that regulates healthcare in the state in which the procedure took place. Then, remember your experience by involving yourself in some capacity that helps other women avoid the circumstances that resemble your experience.

I had a very closely related experience at Mt. Sinai and believe I have PTSD from being forced into a c-section at 37 weeks in 2009. I did not sustain an injury as Mrs. Dray did (because the c-section itself is not considered as such!).  But the the level of rage I have about my experience even now nearly 5 years later is intense. When I was 5 cm dilated at 36+ weeks, my doctors told me on a Friday that they would induce me if I was not in labor by Monday, even though by that point I was still only 37 weeks. I tried to refuse an induction but they said they wanted to "manage the birth" and "deliver me in a controlled fashion." I was told at the Monday check-up that if I left the hospital AMA (against medical advice) they would discontinue my care "and I could just go have my baby on the sidewalk."  After hours of debate, I gave in, had the induction, the baby developed distress, and I had an emergency c-section. The doctor took a cellphone call as I was being rushed down the hall on a stretcher to apologize that my birth was taking too long and that she would be late for dinner. She did not speak to me before during or ether the surgery, clearly furious that I had refused the induction for so long. The natural birth of my first child (with a diff't doc) was the best day of my life and the forced c-section of my second was the worst day of my life. It was a profound violation. C-sections are reimbursed at much higher rate than vaginal deliveries: cause and effect? Reform!!!

I agree with your comment, except the last paragraph.  If there was an urgent need for the section, as seems probable given the hospital's stats on VBAC, a home birth would probably have resulted in a dead mother and/or a dead baby.
Yes, but at least no C-section took place.

This article doesn't give enough information for anyone to have an informed opinion on this particular case. Why did the doctor push for the section? How close together were her pregnancies? Was there an affirmative reason to suspect uterine rupture? Without knowing the answers to any of these questions, this article is mostly a blank slate for most of us to project what we think we know about the high rate of US sections, whether that's good or bad, and imagined motives that this woman might or might not have had.

That said, I will agree with everyone who said she should have gone home birth if she was determined to deliver vaginally.

If a doctor knowingly proceeds with a medical procedure with out the consent of the patients he could be liable for the tort of assualt.  This tort is not one based in negligence but rather in the doctors failure to obtain the informed consent of the patient.

When a plaintiff sues a professional, including a doctor, for professional malpractice, the standard of care against which the defendant's (doctor's) conduct is measured is the standard of care generally provided by a competent, experienced professional in that discipline, in that geographic area.  The plaintiff must produce an expert who will testify (persuasively) that the actual care the defendant provided fell below the appropriate community standard.  What doctor will testify persuasively that the conduct of this doctor (Ducey) fell below generally accepted professional standards?  Even if he acted illegally, or inappropriately, the plaintiff's complaint isn't that there was medical malpractice - in fact, she is almost arguing that there wasn't medical malpractice, but should have been.  The doctor's conduct produced a healthy child - how did he fall short of the appropriate standard of medical care?  In fact, he didn't, and this malpractice case is unlikely to produce anything except a token settlement.
This sounds like a good reason to have the baby at home, and not go near a doctor or a hospital.

This is not a surprise in some states this woman  would or could have been put under arrest for her refusal to have a c section on the basis that she was putting the fetus at risk.  Remember the new trend is the women cannot be trusted and that their judgement must be questioned at every turn and replaced by the state legislature.  The doctors action may have been just abit ahead of its time in NY state.  It is outrageous but it is not surprising in today's world.

No wonder no one wants to go into obstetrics anymore! Not only do they have pregnant mothers with no medical background who have a "birthing plan" they insist on following, exorbitantly high malpractice insurance and a public that will sue for anything that goes wrong including that they have produced a Downs Syndrome baby, and now we are going to have "assertive grandparents" in the delivery room as well.

Sweeping floors looks better to me than this scenario!

I flew to Europe to attend the birth of my grandson an hour ago so this story has particular poignancy.  My English-apeaking daughter hired a midwife to assist with the birth in the public hospital as well as an obstetrician with the hope that the midwife would facilitate her desire for the least medicalized birth process possible.  Anecdotal information in this European country suggests more women are choosing the "convenience" of a c-section.  Her birth was safe and as little medicalized as possible but a woman admitted at the same time elected a c-section.  As the other grandparents and I made our way to her room to join her during labor, I passed women casually nursing babies in the hall - a more relaxed atmosphere than my experience in American hospitals.  If the birth process were permitted to be more of a family affair, perhaps assertive grandparents can derail the physicians' c-section agenda.  I was very vocal about no episiotomy for my daughter to the medical staff and, indeed, she successfully delivered without the convenient cut that makes women's postbirth lives unpleasant.  Paraphrase:  rather than a village, it takes a family....

Every single one of my friends has had a c/s, usually for a bogus reason. The real reason is likely that it keeps the lawyers away. We are all healthy, maybe a little old (I was 34 with my first), but none of us had a truly legitimate reason to get sliced. But everyone just wants to blame the docs, not the lawyers when, if not for the lawyers, who knows how many docs would practice as defensively as they do?

There are many benefits to natural childbirth that cannot be duplicated by c-section, for both the fetus and the mother. There are also many potential surgical and post-operative complications for both. I do not know this mother personally, but if she cared enough about researching docs to support her VBAC, she probably had these in mind, and her actions were in the best interest of her child.
Passing through the vaginal canal squeezes fluid from the lungs of the fetus and can reduce the need for respiratory care, the bacteria in the vagina and near the anus are the first to populate the infant's gut and set the stage for GI development and its immunologic properties thereby protecting the child from infection. Immediate skin to skin puts amniotic fluid on the mother's chest and acts as a "homing beacon" for baby to find the breast over and over during early breastfeeding, it also helps regulate baby's temperature, heart rate and respiratory rate. The mother's satisfaction with her labor and delivery decreases postpartum depression and may play a role in bonding with her child, necessary for the child's survival beyond birth. I hope that you will humbly educate yourself and reconsider your comments such as "she was willing to sacrifice her child to maintain her sense of control. This bears repeating - we are dealing with someone who would rather her child suffer than allow a section." It is likely that she was doing quite the opposite.

@ walterrhett: You're right in that a patient has a right to her body. So, in this case, she should have been discharged while in labor and allowed to give birth naturally somewhere else. She may have a right to how she wants her medical care, but the doctor should also have the right not be be forced to provide care that s/he believes is detrimental to TWO patients because one of them can't be made to see reason. Moreover, what happened to the rights of that baby?

Well, for starters her bladder was cut during the operation. SO she experienced surgical complications from an elective, arguably (likely?) an unnecessary surgery she had opted out of. Seems grounds for a suit to me.

I am a Newborn Intensive Care nurse who has seen the outcome of refusal to have a C-section.  A baby in distress prior to delivery is VERY obvious to the medical professionals in the room...including deep fetal heart rate drops with slow recovery, thick meconium stool in the amniotic fluid, etc.  If immediate intervention is not done, meaning an Emergent C-section, the baby can be born with significant brain damage and long term disabilities.  This woman sounds extremely selfish.  The risks of uterine rupture after having 2 previous c/s is not worth the devastating risks to the baby.  And as a side note, I have seen a repeat scheduled c/s performed on a woman and her uterine wall had ruptured sometime in the past.  The surgeon OB only had an intact bag of water protecting the fetus and if the mom had gone into active labor, this would have been an extremely dangerous situation for both mom and baby!!  Every nurse and doctor in the OR was stunned, and thankful that a decision for c/s had been made in this particular case.  (And I agree with other commentators, if she did not want medical intervention she should have stayed home and risked her life and her baby's life, without increasing the medical liability of every medical professional she encounters because of her extreme lack of knowledge and her own selfish desires!!)

Don't know the specifics but when you employ a physician to treat you you enter into an agreement with him, of which not every contingency is discussed.  The initial agreement with the physician is that you allow him discretion to make decisions for you in difficult circumstances.unless you state to him "under no circumstance will I accept a blood transfusion" (an example in the case of a JW, a person saying they do not want a blood transfusion does not imply they would refuse one in every circumstance).  In the middle of a procedure, with a person in pain, that person may not have the competence to retract their initial consent.  The doctor is really in this circumstance entering into a relationship with two people, the infant has rights which he cannot express. The doctor can be sued if he doesn't consider the well being of the child as well as the wishes of the mother.  Not saying this is what happened here, but it can be a very difficult situation for the doctor.  If the doctor had conceded to the patients immediate desires he might be very much faulted for it afterwards when things turned out bad.  Its a very difficult situation as both the doctor and the patient will undoubtedly have a different view of what transpired once things calm down.

I don't know where Mr. Griswald go his license to practice law or medicine, but I got my license to practice medicine in the United States, and I can confirm absolutely that any intentional and unwanted physical touching is indeed battery, and a crime. Battery with a deadly weapon, such as a knife, even more so.

It makes no difference whether you have agreed to be treated - so long as you are a competent person (not insane, on mind-altering drugs, or demented), you have the right to refuse ANY intervention at ANY time, PERIOD.

Considering that she had a witness (her mother), and considering the doctor's own explicit admission in hos notes, I think she has an excellent case not only for malpractice, abut also for criminal prosecution, and I hope that she wins on both counts.

Any doctor who could write about a competent adult, "I have decided to override her refusal to have a C-section" in the medical record is so accustomed to ignoring the patient's wishes that he should not be practicing medicine.

I am curious how you obtain a court order for an emergency C-section when the mother is on the operating table? Does Fort Worth have a special court part with judges available 24/7 ready to sign these orders?

If the obstetrician can not produce either a court order or a fetal monitor strip showing that the fetus was in severe distress and in need of an emergency c-section, then he is probably guilty of worse than malpractice. A patient has a legal right to refuse treatment. Forcing a patient to submit to treatment without either a court order or without convincing evidence that the treatment had to be done without such an order to save a life is basically assault. If he had the court order or has the monitor strip, then he did what needed to be done---and she can still sue for the bladder laceration.

"For some of us, there is growing disrespect for Congress and the Supreme Court. Elections have become all about money and it is increasingly harmful to the practice of a democratic society."

That is polite understatement.

Many of us are outraged. We want them going to jail.

We don't have real democracy today, because we can only vote for what money allows, and we don't rbrm get what we vote for, just what money buys.

Wow, I just love your concept of civilization. Every time there's something to do with China, there you are feeling so superior. Where's your outrage over genocidal Army general Andrew Jackson still being honored on the $20 bill, who among other acts deliberately sent diseased blankets to Cherokee civilians he helped drive out into the wilds -- in an early attempt at biological warfare and ethnic cleansing??

Americans are MUCH worse: they live in a democracy, they believe, and allow the most outrageous abuses of power to occur despite being FULLY INFORMED: consistently undermining democratically elected governments all around the world or people's movements for democracy -- Japan, Taiwan, South Korea, South Vietnam, the Philippines, Indonesia, Pakistan: Iran, Iraq, Palestine, Saudi Arabia, Egypt, Algeria; Italy, Greece, South Africa, Nigeria....

Oh yeah, and let's not forget US fomenting Tibetan rebellion in the '50s, '60s, and '70s -- then casually tossing aside their "freedom fighters" when political whims changed.

ChiCom policy is frustratingly ham-fisted and uninspired, to be sure, but now you drag the Hui (Tungans) into this and that's just not true what you claim about "brotherly ethnic groups"...in fact, many a Uighur nationalist want not just Hans out of their putative East Turkestan, but also Hui, Mongolians, Tibetans, and even Kazakhs, Uzbeks, and Tajiks -- according to Rudelson's account published during the '90s and Western bloggers reporting on popular sentiment they'd overheard during the 2008 riots.
